block.p: Children and teachers who have second thoughts about dissecting frogs in the name of science can breathe easy. Owl pellets are becoming the teaching tool of choice in schools across the country.
Children and teachers who have second thoughts about dissecting frogs in the name of science can breathe easy. Owl pellets are becoming the teaching tool of choice in schools across the country.

Owls can't digest the bones and fur of the mice and birds they eat, so they regurgitate a daily pellet that looks like a furry cigar butt. The pellets offer an opportunity for nonlethal laboratory work. The matted brown shell (above right) contains the nicely cleaned bones of a night's meal, like the elongated skull of a hummingbird (above left).

Pellet biology has sparked a new industry. The pellets retail for around $1 each, and companies in New York, California and Washington employ collectors to pick up the pellets in barns and under trees where the owls nest. Bret Gaussoin, co-owner of Pellets Inc. of Bellingham, Wash., says his company distributes pellets to 20,000 classrooms in spots as far away as Rome and Pago Pago.

But the new industry may be short-lived, says Gaussoin, because rural America is being gentrified. "We're losing our old barns at a fairly alarming rate. They're being bulldozed down, and when they go, so do the owls."
